bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R. G. Bradshaw, October 30, 1947

div1.p: Hench suggests a title for his upcoming lecture on Reed at the University of Virginia, and notes the key roles played by three University of Virginia alumni in the experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R. G. Bradshaw, October 30, 1947
div1.opener:
October 30, 1947
Mr. R. G. Bradshaw
Secretary, Virginia Chapter
Alpha Omega Alpha
Department of Medicine
University of Virginia
Charlottesville, Virginia
My dear Mr. Bradshaw:
div1.p:
Thank you kindly for your letter of October 18. I am
arranging to arrive in Charlottesville, Monday morning, November 17
and will spend the day at the home of my brother. I will be at
your service during the day and will leave that night for New York
about 10:30 or thereafter. My reservations are being made from
here. Thank you. I will not have to bother you.

You asked for a title for the lecture. How about this one:
“Walter Reed and the Conquest of Yellow Fever”. The title could al-
most be “The University of Virginia and the Conquest of Yellow Fever”
because three alumni were important participants. Namely, Walter Reed,
Johnny Moran and Reed's right hand man--General Jefferson R. Kean.

I believe I wrote Mr. Owen that my lecture will be illustrated
and that I will use standard-size lantern slides. Please give me some
information on two or three points: What time will the lecture be?
Do I have to wear a dinner jacket? I have one if necessary. What
time is the banquet and will it be satisfactory for me to leave for
the 10:57 train, and most important of all, how long should the talk
be? One more question. When was the Alpha Omega Alpha Chapter at the
University of Virginia founded?
div1.closer: Sincerely, Philip S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
